title: The Everest 2019: Yes Yes Yes worth $50m with Everest win
text:
Racing editor Ray Thomas breaks down the 12-strong field that will race The Everest.

Coolmore’s crack sprinter Yes Yes Yes will become racing’s $50 million colt if he wins The TAB Everest at Royal Randwick on Saturday.

Trainer Chris Waller said The Everest has replaced the Golden Slipper as the nation’s most prestigious “stallion-making” race and Yes Yes Yes’s value will soar if he can win the world’s richest turf race.

Yes Yes Yes, the only three-year-old in the field for the $14 million The TAB Everest, has firmed form $11 to $9 for the big race since Tuesday night’s barrier draw on Sydney Harbour Bridge.

Waller said that Yes Yes Yes is ready to race very competitively against some of the world’s best sprinters in The Everest.

“I would say The Everest is regarded as the race to win in terms of a stallion-making race,’’ Waller said.

“The Golden Slipper has been that (race) up to now. Automatically, a colt is worth $30-$40 million minimum if it wins the Slipper, and if it has good breeding then $50 million.

“But if a three-year-old colt can beat the best sprinters in the land then it must put his value up above that as the Golden Slipper is only for two-year-olds.’’

Waller has three starters in The Everest including Arcadia Queen ($5) and Nature Strip ($23).

“It’s a privilege to have three horses in such a great race,’’ Waller said. “The Everest is a talking point around the (racing) world at the moment.’’

Sydney’s premier trainer said The Everest is changing the face of Australian racing and creating interest in the sport to a new generation of younger race fans.

“The Everest is bringing in a new era in racing,’’ he said. “The race is creating a lot of attention with young people who are watching our sport and seeing what it is all about.

“Like all sports, whether it be the introduction of 20-20 cricket, twilight games, Friday night rugby which was never heard of a few years ago, you have got to move with the times.

“If we don’t move with the times, we (racing) will fall behind.’’

Waller said The Everest is helping racing cement its premier sporting position between the months of October and November but chose his words carefully when asked to compare Sydney’s new race with the Melbourne Cup.

“The Melbourne Cup is on the first Tuesday in November and that will never change,’’ he said. “But I think in time The Everest will rival the Melbourne Cup. These are the races you want to win and be recognised for winning.

“If a trainer and jockey can win The Everest it will certainly promote their careers.’’

Waller said the sheer quality of sprinters lining up in the world’s richest turf race was undeniable.

“If you look at the formlines and compare it to other great races, you won’t see as many wins next to their names as you do for The Everest,’’ Waller said. “Most of the slot holders have chosen their horses a long time out and seem to have got it right.

“The Everest has assembled the best sprinters in Australia, in fact the world with the horse coming out from Ireland (Ten Sovereigns), so it has that international quality.

“The great thing about The Everest is that most of the runners have had lead-up races.

“They are not hiding from each other either, they are meeting often and that creates interest.’’
description: Coolmore’s crack sprinter Yes Yes Yes will become racing’s $50 million colt if he wins The TAB Everest at Royal Randwick on Saturday.
